subject: Public Speaking
title: Children vs. Adults: When Fear Develops
description: A micro-lesson that makes Children vs. Adults: When Fear Develops usable.

hook.text: Most five-year-olds will happily speak to a room of strangers. Most adults would rather not. What changed?

buildup.text: Research shows stage fright typically develops between ages 8 and 14, when social awareness sharpens.

discovery.text: This is when children start comparing themselves to peers and worrying about social hierarchy and status.

twist.text: Early negative experiences â€” being laughed at or scolded â€” can crystallize the fear into a lasting pattern.

climax.text: Stage fright isn't innate. It's learned during the years when social belonging becomes psychologically critical.

punchline.text: You weren't born afraid. Adolescence taught you.

quiz.question: When does stage fright typically develop?
